Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An Accessible Platform for Engaging Children with Motor Impairments in the Classroom Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project focuses on developing an accessible educational platform that combines mobile interfaces and adaptive educational tablet applications (Apps) to support the needs of children with special needs. Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with disabilities are largely overlooked due to difficulties in effecting pinch-and-swipe gestures. This project thus addresses a direct need in our society by providing an integrated educational experience, focused on math education that addresses the diverse needs of children, while providing a solution for variations found in their disabilities. The contributions of this project include 1) the design of accessible math Apps usable by K-12 children with and without disabilities and 2) the design of apps that adapt educational content and provide feedback to parents and teachers based on real-time analytics. Given that there are over 93 million children worldwide living with a disability and, in the United States, children with disabilities are entitled to a free appropriate public education, there is a large potential of making both a commercial, as well as a societal, impact in this space.

This SBIR Phase I project addresses an unmet need by developing an innovative solution to enable children with motor disabilities access to mobile devices and Apps that could engage them fully into the educational system. This solution capitalizes on the availability of pervasive technologies by combining an accessible tablet interface and educational Apps that adapt to each child's abilities in order to provide an accessible mobile solution. Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with motor limitations tend to have difficulties due to the fine motor skills required for interaction. As such, to address the growing utilization of tablets in the classroom environment, the specific research objectives of this effort include the design of methods that enable the embedding of educational math content into accessible tablet apps for training and evaluating cognitive skills, the design of methods that enable adaptation of the educational content based on real-time analysis of interaction data and correlated performance of the child, and the hosting of interactive design sessions with teachers, parents, and children to evaluate the usability of the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tablet devices are known to provide an interactive experience that has revolutionized learning for children. Unfortunately, while these tablet devices are intuitive to utilize and easy for many children, those with motor limitations, such as children living with cerebral palsy or recovering from traumatic brain injury, tend to have difficulties due to the fine motor skills required for interaction. As such, as tablet devices are increasingly being integrated into the classroom environment, there is a measurable demographic of children that are not being given equal access. Given that there are over 6.4 million children with disabilities in the U.S, there is a large demographic of children that are now being overlooked by the introduction of tablet devices into the mainstream classroom environment. It seems natural therefore to capitalize on the widespread appeal found with tablet devices and the wealth of educational Apps available to design a system that supports the educational goals of children with disabilities.

As such, in our SBIR Phase I and IB project, we focused on developing an accessible platform for children with motor disabilities that supports their goals in the classroom environment. Specifically, our major goals were to: Design methods that enabled our accessible therapy Apps to embed common core math content in their design for training and evaluating cognitive skills (Phase I); Design methods that enabled adaptation of the educational content based on real-time analysis of interaction data and correlated performance of the child (Phase I); Conduct interactive design sessions with teachers, parents, and children to evaluate usability of the system (Phase I); Develop accessible instructional material that supported the accessible math Apps through STEM literacy (Phase IB).

The Phase I work resulted in an MVP (minimum-viable product) of the components necessary to validate the feasibility of an accessible educational platform and validating the usability and usefulness of the platform in addressing the needs of children with motor disabilities. The outcomes included a functional accessible interface prototype, interactive STEM e-books, and three accessible K-2nd grade math apps that could adapt based on real-time interaction with the child. The conclusions derived from introduction of the MVP versions to teachers, parents, and children validated the market and societal need for a full expansion of the accessible educational platform for children with disabilities. 

Not only have we received a number of awards and recognitions for these accessible math apps, we’ve also hosted a number of workshops that have provided training to special education teachers and administrators. In these workshops, we have discussed the role of accessible STEM and best practices for inclusion of children in STEM activities. We have also had two papers published, participated in four poster sessions and made three public presentations in order to disseminate the results from our SBIR efforts to the communities of interest.
